text: I'm finding that I need to constantly remind people to work together. To collaborate. Really spell out who should be part of the project and in what capacity. It's almost like because people aren't staring at their colleagues every day they forget they exist and what they do. Things get worse when people isolate themselves and don't get help from the rest of the team.

text:
That’s so interesting <@URAV154AV>! I definitely feel it’s made collaboration more challenging but I almost saw the opposite, where too many people were being looped in and spending their time in extra meetings/standups that really weren’t necessary. The extreme clarity on who + how is key. We’re adapting and have made some marketing process changes, as well as company-wide communication recommendations, that have helped a lot, but it’s been an interesting transition.

<@U010JU2GTND> same same same re: a lot more checking in. I know what a lot of people missed was the in-person experience that it simply isn’t possible to recreate 1:1, because work has changed—but I’ve been trying to find new and personalized ways to engage individuals.

text: Following this!!! This is also a challenge we're looking to put down into process

elements.text: Following this!!! This is also a challenge we're looking to put down into process

text: Yeah! We have morning standups 3x/week which spurred as a result of my direct report (we’re a team of 2 so it’s easier to manager) feeling some of that loneliness you’d expect from remote work. So we spend 10-15 minutes just catching up and joking around and then quick status update/what we’re working on which we’d typically just share in a daily thread on slack. But at least this way, we don’t go through a full day without talking to at least one person on the entire team :smile: I feel like that’s helped!

text: I’ve really resisted having standups and team meetings because we already have so many project and cross-functional meetings, but maybe it’s worth trying.

elements.text: I’ve really resisted having standups and team meetings because we already have so many project and cross-functional meetings, but maybe it’s worth trying.

text: Yeah it was good perspective for me because I was in meetings constantly (which has improved lately) so I wanted as few as possible…but a couple people on my team mentioned that they could go an entire day or two without “seeing” anyone. We have a weekly Content Team standup now but I try to be more cognizant of even little 1:1 outreach or starting a chatty Slack thread if there’s a week where we don’t have our larger team/project meetings.

elements.text: Yeah it was good perspective for me because I was in meetings constantly (which has improved lately) so I wanted as few as possible…but a couple people on my team mentioned that they could go an entire day or two without “seeing” anyone. We have a weekly Content Team standup now but I try to be more cognizant of even little 1:1 outreach or starting a chatty Slack thread if there’s a week where we don’t have our larger team/project meetings.

text: I have a feeling as leaders we are overindexed on meetings. My big push lately for myself has been to back out of as many projects and meetings as possible and delegate to my team. When we were lean in 2020 I got in the habit of getting involved in everything and it has to stop!

elements.text: I have a feeling as leaders we are overindexed on meetings. My big push lately for myself has been to back out of as many projects and meetings as possible and delegate to my team. When we were lean in 2020 I got in the habit of getting involved in everything and it has to stop!

text: I would keep plugging away, eventually you will get a better sense for who you can trust … it’s hard when you are just starting out but there’s not really a shortcut. Eventually you’ll find people who are trustworthy, knowledgeable, and responsive … a few at first, then hopefully more as you keep going.

elements.text: I would keep plugging away, eventually you will get a better sense for who you can trust … it’s hard when you are just starting out but there’s not really a shortcut. Eventually you’ll find people who are trustworthy, knowledgeable, and responsive … a few at first, then hopefully more as you keep going.

text:
We went through a few M&As right before COVID hit so we had a sudden shift to remote only PLUS the challenge of combining a bunch of global companies.

Took a while to get there, but we've tried to give our team more channels to connect on a personal level, like topic-specific chat channels (pets, the outdoors, tv, books). We also do bi-weekly coffee chats where staff get paired up randomly to get to know each other. We also have a wellness committee now that hosts virtual stretching/yoga sessions. We also did a steps challenge that went over well. Those things have certainly help create more connections.
